Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: MIT in Nashik: Creating a Model for Smart Citizens

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research examines the technology challenges with providing services to pop-up cities. Pop-up cities are locations where the population expands very rapidly by an order of magnitude or more in a very short time. One of these examples is provided by the Kumbh Mela in India. This event is expected to attract 30 million pilgrims to the city of Nashik, India in late summer and early fall 2015. This proposal is a RAPID and is designed to collect data on crowd and service needs for a pop-up city. The information will relate to crowd dynamics and infrastructure needs.

The proposal offers the opportunity to collect huge amounts of data that can be used for analyzing infrastructure and services needs due to emergent pop-up cities. The data is time perishable and can only be collected when the event is in progress. The data can be mined to enable the understanding of requirements for smart and connected communities when a rapid community growth occurs over a short but extended period. The research will provide insights into how much infrastructure needs to be built-up well in advance (for example supporting Olympic Events or similar large gatherings) and how much can be created just in time. It will help identify service needs spanning many of the technologies needed by smart and connected communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Rapid fund was used to create, implement and refine a framework to empower smart citizens to solve grand challenges and realize significant social impact. The Kumbh Mela festival in Nashik, India provided a driving force and an opportunity. The event transformed Nashik into a pop-up city with 30 million visitors. 

The Emerging Worlds team led Kumbhathons or “buildathons” in Nashik and at the Media Lab to SPOT problems and PROBE alternative solutions. The team convened innovators from across India, state and local government officials, community leaders, business executives, entrepreneurs, and mentors from the US and India. Everyone was motivated to realize a common goal: to make the Kumbh Mela a safe and enjoyable event for all. Beyond that, the objectives were to: leverage data and digital technology, develop innovation talent and capacity, identify approaches and solutions that could help other pop-up cities, utilize the model in order to solve additional problems in emerging economies, and improve the lives of many people.

 

The framework leverages human capital, data, and digital technologies. The framework was tested and proven at the Kumbh Mela – a religious pilgrimage that attracted 30 million visitors to the city of Nashik, India in August and September 2015. During the Kumbh Mela the MIT Media Lab team collected, analyzed and utilized large quantities of data on human behavior and uses of key infrastructure components. The 2015 Kumbh Mela in Nashik was recognized as India’s safest major festival on record. There were zero major incidents (no stampedes, no loss of life, no missing persons, and no epidemic outbreaks).

Several solutions were launched at the Kumbh Mela. Two that we worked with in particular were EpiMetrics, an epidemic tracker, and Crowd Steering, a crowd management tool. 

As a result of the successful Kumbh Mela, the city of Nashik is now one of India’s Smart Cities.

Solutions launched

Multiple solutions were launched at the Kumbh Mela, including: 

Medi Tracker – Quick ambulance service, using GPS coordinates and hospital notification

Crowd Steering – Mapping of crowd movements using cell phone tower data

3D Map – 3-dimensional, elevated map of Nashik for easy directions, especially for people who can’t read local languages

Wiki Nashik – Initiative to update Nashik wiki page to assist tourists and visitors

Nashik Trimbak Kumbh App – named the official portal for all Kumbh Mela-related information from maps to food to emergency assistance

Pop-up Housing – frame-based housing that can be constructed in only 3 days. Had an installation in the government-sponsored Kumbh Mela temporary housing area in Nashik

Crowd Tracking - real-time people counting system that can be used for counting large crowds

Kumbha Sahayak – a helpline service that provides automated information

Annandan – an optimized supply chain for donated and homemade food

GG Talk – A platform that allows you to upload images, update information and send messages related to track incidents

EpiMetrics – an application which identifies and controls epidemic outbreak. Its unique algorithm collects symptoms and enables prediction.

These solutions were all created, tested and implemented in collaboration with the Nashik government. In fact, the government was so pleased with the MIT Media Lab and the approach that 40 delegates visited the MIT Media Lab after the event.
